SENT.plain: Lemierre's syndrome comprises internal jugular vein thrombosis following oropharyngeal sepsis and is a rare and serious condition
It is most commonly caused by the anaerobe Fusobacterium necrophorum and typically presents as metastatic sepsis to the lungs and joints
Thrombosis is demonstrated by computed tomography (CT) of the neck, and it is routinely treated with intravenous antibiotics and anti-coagulation
We describe a case of Lemierre's syndrome following acute supraglottitis
The clinical features were of retrograde intracranial thrombosis, rather than the more usual metastatic sepsis
